Situation1: They guide a patient on proper usage and potential side effects of a new prescription medication.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A member of the community has scheduled an appointment to discuss a persistent personal struggle.
Story: I glanced at the clock on the pharmacy wall, my white coat feeling heavier than usual. Mrs. Lee stood before me, clutching her new prescription, her eyes anxious as she asked about side effects. I knew she needed careful counseling—her medical history was complicated, and she trusted me to guide her safely. As I began to explain, my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a reminder: Mr. Alvarez, a parishioner, was waiting at the church office. He’d confided in me last Sunday about a struggle weighing on his soul, and today was the only time he could meet. My mind raced. As a pharmacist, I owed Mrs. Lee my full attention and expertise. As a priest, I was Mr. Alvarez’s lifeline, expected to offer comfort and spiritual counsel. Both needed me, right now, in different ways. My heart pounded as I tried to focus on Mrs. Lee’s questions, but guilt gnawed at me, knowing someone else was waiting for hope only I could offer.
